questions.prompt: What is the capital city of Northern Ireland?
questions.explanation: The capital city of Northern Ireland is Belfast.

questions.prompt: What name is given to the day when people play jokes on each other until midday?
questions.explanation: April Fool’s Day, 1 April, is a day when people play jokes on each other until midday. The television and newspapers often have stories that are April Fool jokes.

questions.prompt: Who is the fastest person to have sailed around the world single-handed?
questions.explanation: Dame Ellen MacArthur (1976-) is a yachtswoman and in 2004 became the fastest person to sail around the world singlehanded.

questions.prompt: When did the First World War end?
questions.explanation: The First World War ended at 11.00 am on 11th November 1918 with victory for Britain and its allies.

questions.prompt: What are Welsh cakes made of?
options: Bacon, eggs, sausage, black pudding and potato bread
questions.explanation: Welsh cakes are a traditional Welsh snack made from flour, dried fruits and spices, and served either hot or cold.

questions.prompt: Where is the London Eye situated?
options: On the northern bank of the River Thames
On the southern bank of the River Thames
On the northern bank of the River Lea
On the southern bank of the River Lea
questions.explanation: The London Eye is situated on the southern bank of the River Thames and is a Ferris wheel that is 443 feet (135 metres) tall.

questions.prompt: What is the relationship between the monarch and the government?
options: Approve the government’s decisions on government policies
Advise, warn and encourage the government’s decisions
Advise, encourage and approve the government’s decisions
Advise and approve the government’s decisions
questions.explanation: The monarch has regular meetings with the Prime Minister and can advise, warn and encourage, but the decisions on government policies are made by the Prime Minister and cabinet.

questions.prompt: The UK is a ‘constitutional monarchy’:
questions.explanation: The UK has a constitutional monarchy.

questions.prompt: What do you need to apply to become a permanent resident or citizen of the UK (Choose TWO options)?
options: To be able to speak and read English
A good understanding of life in the UK
questions.explanation: To apply to become a permanent resident or citizen of the UK, you will need to speak and read English and have a good understanding of life in the UK.

questions.prompt: Which British scientist was awarded a Nobel Prize for discovering the structure of the DNA molecule?
questions.explanation: The structure of the DNA molecule was discovered in 1953 through work at British universities in London and Cambridge. This discovery contributed to many scientific advances, particularly in medicine and fighting crime. Francis Crick (1916-2004), one of those awarded the Nobel Prize for this discovery, was British.

questions.prompt: Who established the Church of England?
questions.explanation: To divorce his first wife, Henry VIII needed the approval of the Pope. When the Pope refused, Henry established the Church of England. In this new church, the king, not the Pope, would have the power to appoint bishops and order how people should worship.

questions.prompt: When does Lent take place?
questions.explanation: The 40 days before Easter are known as Lent. It is a time when Christians take time to reflect and prepare for Easter.

questions.prompt: Which of the following national galleries is NOT located in London?
questions.explanation: The National Museum is located in Cardiff, Wales.

questions.prompt: How much can you be fined if you watch TV but do not have a TV licence?
questions.explanation: You will receive a fine up to £1,000 if you watch TV but do not have a TV licence.

questions.prompt: How old is the clock at the Houses of Parliament in London, also known as ‘Big Ben’?
questions.explanation: Big Ben is the nickname for the great bell of the clock at the House of Parliament in London. The clock is over 150 years old and is a popular tourist attraction.

questions.prompt: The UK was a full member of the European Union but did not use the Euro currency.
questions.explanation: This statement is true.

questions.prompt: The North Atlantic Treaty Organisation is a group of European and North American countries that was created with which TWO purposes:
options: Protect and promote human rights in those countries
Help each other if they come under attack
Maintain peace between all its members
Promote free trade amongst those countries
questions.explanation: NATO is a group of European and North American countries that have agreed to help each other if they come under attack. It also aims to maintain peace between all of its members.

questions.prompt: The small claims procedure is used in England and Wales for minor disputes for:
questions.explanation: This procedure is used for claims of less than £10,000 in England and Wales and £3,000 in Scotland and Northern Ireland.

questions.prompt: What name is given to the period in the 18th century when new ideas about politics, philosophy and science were developed?
questions.explanation: During the 18th century, new ideas about politics, philosophy and science were developed. This is often called ‘the Enlightenment’.

questions.prompt: What is the meaning of ‘Magna Carta’?
questions.explanation: The Magna Carta (which means the Great Charter). The Magna Carta established the idea that even the king was subject to the law. It protected the rights of the nobility and restricted the king’s power to collect taxes or to make and change laws.

questions.prompt: When did the Wars of the Roses end?
questions.explanation: The Wars of the Roses ended with the Battle of Bosworth Field in 1485.

questions.prompt: Which of the following is the responsibility of the Chancellor of the Exchequer?
questions.explanation: The Chancellor of the Exchequer is responsible for the economy.

questions.prompt: In which British university did Isaac Newton study?
questions.explanation: Isaac Newton studied at Cambridge University.

questions.prompt: Who invaded England after the Romans?
questions.explanation: The Roman army left Britain in AD 410 to defend other parts of the Roman Empire and never returned. Britain was again invaded by tribes from northern Europe: the Jutes, the Angles and the Saxons.
